node.title: How to define the grid power distribution when using the thermal hydraulics module?
node.bodyText:
Holle
I now have the power distribution data in the form of a geometric matrix like following.
     x -10 -9 ... 8 9 10
y
-10   1    2 . . . 3 2 1 # power data
-9
.
.
.8
9
10

Which object can I use to add this type  data to the thermal hydraulic moudule. Do I need to fit it as a function?
Thanks

Hello
There are a number of functions that can load this. There's piecewisemultilinear for example.
A Function will be a widely supported format.
What are the two coordinates?
component number an axial coordinate?
Guillaume

node.title: Error with mesh created with gmsh: "ERROR: Expected boundary element of dimension 2 but.."

node.bodyText: Files saved with the .inp extension are processed as Abaqus files. If you want the gmsh reader you will need to use the .msh extension

So, gmsh can apparently export files in the Abaqus format. However, I tried exporting in the gmsh format and still got an error:
*** ERROR ***
map_find() error: key "26" not found in file ../src/mesh/gmsh_io.C on line 508
Stack frames: 18
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: libMesh::MacroFunctions::report_error(char const*, int, char const*, char const*, std::ostream&)
2: std::map<unsigned int, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition, std::less<unsigned int>, std::allocator<std::pair<unsigned int const, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition> > >::mapped_type& libMesh::Utility::map_find<std::map<unsigned int, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition, std::less<unsigned int>, std::allocator<std::pair<unsigned int const, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition> > >, unsigned int, (unsigned int*)0>(std::map<unsigned int, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition, std::less<unsigned int>, std::allocator<std::pair<unsigned int const, libMesh::GmshIO::ElementDefinition> > >&, unsigned int const&, char const*, int)
3: libMesh::GmshIO::read_mesh(std::istream&)
4: libMesh::GmshIO::read(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
5: libMesh::NameBasedIO::read(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
6: libMesh::UnstructuredMesh::read(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, void*, bool, bool)
7: FileMesh::buildMesh()
8: MooseMesh::init()
9: SetupMeshAction::act()
10: Action::timedAct()
11: ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
12: ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions()
13: MooseApp::runInputFile()
14: MooseApp::run()
15: main
16: __libc_start_main
17: ./farm-opt(+0x33ef) [0x5599600983ef]
[0] ./include/libmesh/utility.h, line 134, compiled Apr 20 2023 at 15:32:43

What could this be referring to?

Did you try to load the *.msh file using your app with --mesh-only options?
Is an error message also displayed? Or just when you try to run the entire simulation?
I don't have a suitable input file to use your mesh, but simply loading and creating an exodus works for me and can be viewed in paraview.

I used an updated version of gmsh (4.11, I was using 4.9) to make the mesh in .msh format and it seems like its working (no errors like before). But-
I just tried the --mesh-only flag and it did output a .e file which, when I viewed in paraview, was just a surface. When I selected "volume" it was empty, and I didn't see the spherical refinement I did (were you able to see it?)
Also, running the program again with --mesh-only gives the same output on the console but doesn't create a .e file anymore (it only created one the first time).
Now I'm REALLY confused. I don't know if its my computer at this point.
--mesh-only creates a <input_name>_in.e file
@1runer in the .e file output with the --mesh-only flag, do you get a solid volume mesh or just a surface? are you able to see the semisphere where I increased the mesh refinement?

It looks to me that your mesh is not properly defined in the .geo-file.
Opening/Meshing with Gmsh shows to me two blocks: A big cube and attached a super thin cube.
The sphere is in the geometry file but not in the meshed result.
Did you embed the internal surfaces into the 3D volume? This is needed to have a conforming mesh following the internal curves of the sphere.
Did you define a Physical Volume for the sphere?
If both answers are no, you have simply created two unconnected meshes in Gmsh. And since the sphere must be defined as a Physical Volume, it is simply deleted in the output to .msh.

@1runer
That's right, I have one large cube and one super thin cube on top of it as you were able to see. I'm surprised that the semisphere didn't show up for you though. I just reloaded the .geo file with the script above and this is what I have:

I defined internal surfaces for the sphere but did not define a volume, as it is embedded within two existing volumes and isn't really a volume itself. Its a "dummy" shape for refinement of that specific area. This is the mesh I get after meshing:

But when I export this same thing to MOOSE, the output mesh I get is just a hollow surface cube when I view in paraview (not even a volume at all):

Do you have any idea what could be the problem here?

If I click the mesh 3D button, I get a 3D mesh and a lot of warnings because of the bad aspect ratio of the small cube. But it meshes 3D.
You have to explicitly embed the lines/surfaces in the volume to have a conforming mesh. There is a command for doing it.
Otherwise you create two unconnected meshes.
Gmsh just outputs parts of any mesh which are assigned to a physical volume.
Please see the Gmsh tutorial how to do so.

@1runer after battling with this yesterday I'm convinced the issue in MOOSE was that the original mesh was unconnected. Thanks! However, using either BooleanFragments or Coherence in gmsh to make the mesh conform made the physical groups I initially defined disappear, and I unfortunately have not found a way to redefine those groups. I'll mark this as answered since the actual problem was figured out.

node.title: Periodic BCs with split mesh
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Should periodic BCs work with a split mesh?
I have a case where I am loading in a mesh file which is periodic, and translational BCs are accepted as expected when the mesh is replicated, and also if distributed without pre-splitting the mesh.
However, if I pre-split the mesh, I get the following error:
Periodic boundary neighbor not found
Is this behaviour expected, and is there any way to apply periodic BCs to large meshes which need splitting?
Thanks!

I am pretty sure there is a discussion post about this somewhere involving @ttruster. The issue is that when you split the mesh, the ghosting functors for the periodic neighbors are likely not run. If you ran your splitting mesh input with all the algebraic objects from your simulation input, even though you are not actually using them, I am curious whether things would work, since they should add their ghosting needs for consideration when the mesh is split.
Yes the discussion is in here: #24140. The current framework functions if the mesh is split after the periodic boundaries are loaded, i.e. if it is split at runtime.
Ah, nice, that makes sense. Is running mesh splitting with all algebraic objects something I can try? I haven't seen anything in the docs, so not sure how you'd go about this...
Just use the exact same input file as you would use to run your simulation, use the mesh generators you use to generate your mesh, and run that with --mesh-only
Ah I see, I had already tried this - unfortunately no difference, periodic BCs are still not picked up.
that's very interesting. That's something we should debug. I'm going to transfer this to an issue

Okay - I have double checked this morning, so just to be extra clear on what does and doesn't work:

Replicated mesh work fine
Loading the raw mesh file with FileMeshGenerator, defining other subdomains etc in the Mesh block, and later specifying a translational periodic BC works fine with parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED and --distributed-mesh. (Maybe interesting is I can't get the auto-detection to work even though the translation is orthogonal. I wondered if this only works with Moose generated meshes?)
Running this same file with --mesh-only, then using FileMeshGenerator to load in the resulting exodus file also works fine with parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED and --distributed-mesh.
Using --split-mesh for either of these cases (the raw mesh file, or the --mesh-only exodus file) and loading the resulting .cpr files in FileMeshGenerator does not work. Both cases result in the error Periodic boundary neighbor not found.

So it seems that it is fine with anything where the mesh is replicated at some stage, even if parts are then deleted on each processor. However, anything where the mesh is pre-split does not work.
I haven't tried this with any other mesh formats yet. These tests were all using the gmsh .msh format.
I've opened #25158 to track this

Thanks - thinking about this, there is some other behaviour which could be relevant here, which is when I see the error message:
If I attempt to use auto-detected BCs, I get an error saying they could not be found immediately.
However, specifying the translation, I typically have to wait longer for the error to appear, and other information is output first - for example, TensorMechanics Action: selecting 'incremental finite strain' formulation in a simulation with tensor mechanics.
I'm not sure what order everything is supposed to happen, but I wonder if only the automatically detected periodic BCs are handled when other algebraic objects are, but for some reason other types such as translational are not?
It seems strange that it appears to be searching for the periodic neighbours at different times depending on the formulation. Since the translational seems to happen later than some other initial steps, this could be linked to why it is not implemented when running --mesh-only

node.title: Exception handler for SolutionUserobject
node.bodyText:
Hi,
if we repetitively (and automatized) want to run an input file using the previous simulations exodus, the SolutionUserobject is a good option to import ICs, Variables, Auxvariables etc.
The only problem occurs on the very first iteration if the file or variable specified under "mesh =" doesn't exist. Then the simulation will terminate immediately.
One option would be to create an empty dummy variable e.g. using Paraview.
How much hassle is it to add some kind of exception handler, e.g. to replace the missing variable with "0" or at least not terminate it before the function block is called and an if-else case could be executed in it?
Exemplary input file:
[Mesh]
  # [generatedMesh]
  #   type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
  #   dim = 2
  #   nx = 10
  #   xmin = 0
  #   xmax = 30
  #   ny = 5
  #   ymin = 0
  #   ymax = 10
  # []
  [fileMesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = importtest_exodus.e
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  gravity = '0 -9.81 0'
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
[]

[Variables]
  [pp]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [permeability]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  # [permeability]
  #   type = PorousFlowPropertyAux
  #   variable = permeability
  #   property = permeability
  #   column = 0
  #   row = 0
  # []
  [PermFunction]
    type = FunctionAux
    function = permSolution
    variable = permeability
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [pouter]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = pp
    function = 'hydrostatic'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [pouter]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = pp
    boundary = 'right'
    function = 'hydrostatic'
  []
  [pleft]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = pp
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 2.5e7
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [mass0]
    type = PorousFlowFullySaturatedMassTimeDerivative
    variable = pp
  []
  [adv0]
    type = PorousFlowFullySaturatedDarcyFlow
    variable = pp
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [dictator]
    type = PorousFlowDictator
    porous_flow_vars = 'pp'
    number_fluid_phases = 1
    number_fluid_components = 1
  []
  [importPerm]
    type = SolutionUserObject
    mesh = importtest_exodus.e
    system_variables = permeability2
    allow_duplicate_execution_on_initial = true
    timestep = 'LATEST'
  []
[]

[FluidProperties]
  [fluid]
    type = SimpleFluidProperties
    bulk_modulus = 2e9
    density0 = 1000
    viscosity = 1e-3
    thermal_expansion = 0
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [hydrostatic]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '18e6 + (9.81 * 1000 * (10-y))'
  []
  [permException]
    # Error before this can be called
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'if(importPerm > 0, importPerm, 1e-12)'
  []
  [permSolution]
    type = SolutionFunction
    solution = importPerm
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [temperature]
    type = PorousFlowTemperature
  []
  [ppss]
    type = PorousFlow1PhaseFullySaturated
    porepressure = pp
  []
  [massfrac]
    type = PorousFlowMassFraction
  []
  [fluid]
    type = PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid
    fp = fluid
    phase = 0
  []
  [poro_matrix]
    type = PorousFlowPorosityConst
    porosity = 1
  []
  [diff1]
    type = PorousFlowDiffusivityConst
    diffusion_coeff = '0'
    tortuosity = 1.0
  []
  # [permeability_matrix]
  #   type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
  #   permeability = '1e-12 0 0  0 1e-12 0  0 0 0'
  # []
  [permeability_matrix]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConstFromVar
    perm_xx = permeability
    perm_yy = permeability
    perm_zz = permeability
  []
  [biot]
    type = PorousFlowConstantBiotModulus
    biot_coefficient = 1
  []
  [relp]
    type = PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityConst
    phase = 0
    kr = 1
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  active = 'mumps'
  [mumps]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options = '-ksp_diagonal_scale -ksp_diagonal_scale_fix -ksp_gmres_modifiedgramschmidt'
    petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -pc_factor_shift_type -snes_rtol -snes_atol -snes_max_it'
    petsc_options_value = 'gmres      lu       mumps                         NONZERO               1E-7       1E-7       50'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  end_time = 100
  dtmax = 10
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1
    growth_factor = 3
  []
  # controls for nonlinear iterations
  l_max_its = 50
[]

[Outputs]
  print_linear_residuals = true
  perf_graph = true
  [exodus]
    type = Exodus
  []
[]


Best

Hello
I would say pass active / inactive parameters to the Functions / UOs blocks to turn on/off objects in the first or the later simulations.
Exception handling based on input file parsing errors has not historically been needed.
Guillaume

Sounds like an idea.
Making a standard input-file and overwriting the input for the first iteration by command line.
I think this could be a useful feature for the future.

node.title: Seeking Guidance on Integrating Machine Learning with MOOSE Framework for Nuclear Reactor Optimization Dissertation
node.bodyText:
Good afternoon,
I am reaching out to this community in search of help and guidance for my upcoming dissertation. With a background in nuclear mechanical engineering and having been on a degree apprenticeship since 2019, I am now embarking on an exciting research project.
Background:
Throughout my academic journey, I've acquired proficiency in modules like CFD, FEA, Engineering Mathematics, MATLAB, Thermofluidic Systems, Stress, and Dynamics. My focus has also extended to nuclear-centric subjects such as reactor physics, reactor chemistry, and reactor materials.
Project Interest:
While researching for my project, I came across the NEAMS framework and am intrigued by the possibility of integrating it into my work. My goal is to develop a dissertation topic centered on the use of Machine Learning (ML) or genetic algorithms to optimize a component used in a nuclear reactor.
Preliminary Idea:
My initial discussion with my university supervisor has led me to consider the question: "Can ML be used to optimize the design of (BLANK) to increase/decrease the (BLANK)?" An example direction might be "Utilization of Machine Learning for Heat Exchanger Optimization."
Primary Question:
My primary question for this community is whether ML can be implemented with the MOOSE framework. If so, who can I contact to discuss how this would work? I am eager to explore this avenue and would greatly appreciate any insights or contacts.
Request for Feedback:
I would welcome any comments, suggestions, or discussions about my dissertation proposal, especially if I can align it to current research being carried out in the field. Your expertise and perspectives would be invaluable to my project.
I look forward to your response and thank you in advance for your time and consideration.
Best regards,
Harry Burgess
HBurgess173.HB@gmail.com

Hello
We have ML capabilities through our integration of libtorch in the framework. We can build, train and use neural networks inside multiphysics solves essentially. You could leverage this for optimization by relying on a reduced order model (ROM) to perform the optimization steps (and the higher fidelity multiphysics to build that ROM)
I'm assuming you are pursuing doctoral studies in the UK.
I would recommend you work with your advisor in the UK to devise an optimization problem relevant to the nuclear industry. There are a number of innovative European advanced reactor designs that would be good study topics for example. We use tools based on MOOSE to study US designs already
Best
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for getting back to me.
Currently, I'm working towards my Bachelor's degree, but I have ambitions to delve deeper into this research at the Master's level, which is a step before a doctoral.
Regarding the libtorch framework, do you have any training resources or perhaps a research paper where it's been utilized? I've only recently discovered its potential and am eager to explore its capabilities for my research.
Since I'm relatively new to this domain, could you guide me on how to acquaint myself with cutting-edge European advanced reactor designs and emerging technologies that might be pertinent to my research?
Appreciate your assistance,
Harry

node.title: ElementPropertyReadFile
node.bodyText:
Dear All,
I am vert new to MOOSE. I was trying to run a tensor mechanics test using ElementPropertyReadFile to read a .csv file. Although I have made make -j4 in the tensor mechanics folder and I can see the  tensor_mechanics-op there, however I still can not use the ElementPropertyReadFile, could you please advise on how to enable that function. Thanks.

Hello
This object is now named PropertyReadFile
is your input file somewhat old?
what error do you get?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I am using this file prop_grain_read_cp_03.i from https://github.com/PengWei97/monkey/blob/main/problem/poly_cp/prop_grain_read_cp_03.i. The error I am getting is : *** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "prop_read", of type "ElementPropertyReadFile".
Thanks

what is the actual error?
you seem to have only pasted the header of the error

Hi Guillame,
Here is the error:
*** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:
/projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/examples/prop_grain_read_cp_03.i:53: (Functions/tdisp/value):
The parameter 'value' is deprecated.
Use 'expression' instead.
*** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:
***** Invalid Object: ElementPropertyReadFile *****
Expired on Thu Jul  1 01:00:00 2021
Update your application using the 'PropertyReadFile' object

*** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/examples/prop_grain_read_cp_03.i:65: (UserObjects/prop_read/ngrain):
The parameter 'ngrain' is deprecated.
ngrain is deprecated, use nvoronoi instead
*** Info ***
TensorMechanics Action: selecting 'total small strain' formulation. Use `incremental = true` to select 'incremental small strain' instead.

Thanks
These are not errors. They are deprecation messages. They are pretty clear on what you need to do to fix your input as well

node.title: How to obtain/output the profile of a variable along a specific direction
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Assuming that I have a 2D simulation, how to obtain the value profile of a variable say D along the Y-axis direction (i.e. X=0) via Postprocessor? In other words, how to obtain the value of variable D along the red line as shown below.

Many thanks!

Hello
You can use the LineValueSampler vectorpostprocessor for this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/LineValueSampler.html
Guillaume
Thanks Guillaume!!

Hi Guillaume,
May I also ask is it possible to output the sampler results every n time steps (e.g. n = 20) rather than just the default n=1? Thanks very much
Qingpei

Hello
Right now it can be done with the controls system.
It s a little difficult to set up.
we are working on a simpler system. For now I would just let it execute too often.
Guillaume
Thanks Guillaume. Got it!

node.title: Website is down
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
the mooseframework is reachable again, however I am not able to update my conda distribution. I even tried removing everything and starting from scratch but I keep getting the following error:
conda install moose-tools
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): failed
CondaHTTPError: HTTP 000 CONNECTION FAILED for url https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64/current_repodata.json
Elapsed: -
An HTTP error occurred when trying to retrieve this URL.
HTTP errors are often intermittent, and a simple retry will get you on your way.
'https//conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64'
It seems to me there are some server issues on the INL side, or am I missing something?
Edit: it seems this is a similar problem as in #25148
The Framework is now also down, again.

Thanks for reporting!
We've definitely been experiencing network issues here at the INL. As I walked in this morning, both resources appear to be functional once more.
I have been having issues since yesterday, still everything dead on my side. Hopefully it will be better tomorrow.
I am using Verizon wireless, and can access both sites. Publicly, it appears available. What network service are you using?
I have been trying from my office, home and mobile network, so i doubt it's a network issue (I should mention I am from Germany).
Oh that is interesting... when using this service: https://www.locabrowser.com/, and selecting Germany, I get a "No response" operation.
Canada works, Japan does not... I can't tell if this is somehow restricted from my machine or not. Still, I will report it to our network team...

@marinsiebert Can you post a screen shot of what occurs when you attempt to browse to https://mooseframework.inl.gov ?
I am being asked to provide some data while we attempt to resolve this issue. Thanks!!

To elaborate a little more, INL's "Information Management" division is asking us, the MOOSE team, to "prove it". Sorry for the hassle, but hopefully with your help we can help get through to them that they're making things a real pain for our broader global community

Right now it works fine again on my phone using wifi, mobile data stays silent however (screenshot attached).
Will try again in the morning on my laptop to reach the site and create the conda environment.
As I posted this I was able to connect to the website, the rest I will try tomorrow
It's better for us to have the screenshot showing it's not working 😄 Thank you so much!

Everything seems to working fine now as I am able to reach the website and update both conda and the framework without issues on my WSL (although I did get the same error during tests as was mentioned in #23042 ; exporting DISPLAY=:0.0 like described worked as a fixed for me)

node.title: Timeout issue when creating moose environment.
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I'm reaching out as a newcomer to both Moose and the Linux system. I'm currently working on setting up Moose on the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) following the official guidelines. However, I'm encountering issues while trying to build the Moose environment using the "mamba create -n moose moose-dev" command. The process fails multiple times with:
_Looking for: ['moose-dev']
https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64      ??.?MB @  ??.?MB/s 0 failed 10.0s
Download error (28) Timeout was reached [https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch/repodata.json]
Could not resolve host: conda.software.inl.gov_
Interestingly, there are instances when I manage to successfully download some of the packages, but the process fails due to timeouts partway through. I'm a bit baffled by this situation since I'm in Australia and I believe there shouldn't be any restrictions on website access from my location.
I'm hoping that someone with more experience could kindly assist me in resolving this issue. Your insights and guidance would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you,
Zinn

Hello
We've had network issues earlier this week. I did not hear that they hit our conda packages but maybe they did.
Do you have another machine you could try from? Just to check if the issues are tied to your machine WSL or not
Guillaume

Hi, Guillaume.
Thanks for the information.
Yes, I have try another machine, and it also meet the same issue. After numerous attempts, I was finally able to successfully install all those packages.
Thank you!
Best,
Zinn

There was another user who had the same issue. They were able to solve the timeouts by increasing the threshold:
conda config --set remote_read_timeout_secs new_time_out
where new_time_out was something greater than the default 60 seconds. Something like this definitely belongs on our troubleshooting page...
Created an issue to add this little hint to our troubleshooting page: #25152

I appreciate your suggestions, but the solution provided didn't yield the desired results in my case. Despite executing the command "conda config --set remote_read_timeout_secs 120," the timeout limitation persists at 10 seconds. Could this issue potentially be attributed to my use of Mamba for package installation instead of Conda?

It could also be related to another issue being reported by this individual: #25149
Using a web browser, are you able to peruse to this meta URL: https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch/repodata.json
If so, what happens when you use curl instead of a web browser (testing that your network connection works from a terminal session):
curl https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch/repodata.json
No, I can't connect to that URL now, but a few hours ago, I successfully connected. I am in Australia.
I'm currently unable to access the official website of MOOSE as well (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/).

Thank you for reporting! Looks like our servers are somehow blocking certain ranges of IPs... I've reported the issue to our network department (and we will voice the importance of getting this solved!).

@BrownieLL, can you post a screen shot of what occurs when you attempt to navigate to: https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch/repodata.json
This is a request from my IM department. We would like some quantifiable artifacts to proceed with
Sorry, I was sleeping at that time. I can access to that URL now.

node.title: MOOSE website & conda packages currently unavailable in some geographical regions
node.bodyText:
We are aware of a service interruption in some countries. We are in contact with INL information management to resolve this.

The MOOSE website is partially unreachable
conda/mamba packages cannot be downloaded

I would strongly advise you do not attempt to update MOOSE or your application if you reside in the affected countries until this is resolved, as you will not be able to update the moose-libmesh package.
If you need access to the documentation, please build it locally:
cd moose/modules
make -j 6
cd doc
python moosedocs.py build --serve
"navigate to the IP shown in the terminal using your internet browser"

Thank you to the community members who reported this issue.
